chapter.htmlHeader: How should I assess a person presenting with a first seizure?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
Assessment of a person presenting with a first seizure should include asking about:

  • Any risk factors suggesting a predisposition for epilepsy.
  • Clinical features suggesting other causes of seizures, or an alternative diagnosis to epilepsy.
  • What happened before, during and after the attack (from the patient and an eyewitness). This should include:
    • Any subjective symptoms at the start of the seizure (aura)  — suggestive of focal epilepsy; these may provide information on where the seizure might arise.
    • Any potential triggers, for example sleep deprivation, stress, light sensitivity, or alcohol use.
    • Specific features of the seizure, for example: 
      • Short-lived (less than 1 minute), abrupt, generalised muscle stiffening (may cause a fall) with rapid recovery — suggestive of tonic seizure.
      • Generalised stiffening and subsequent rhythmic jerking of the limbs, urinary incontinence, tongue biting —suggestive of a generalised tonic-clonic seizure.
      • Behavioural arrest — indicative of absence seizure.
      • Sudden onset of loss of muscle tone — suggestive of atonic seizure.
      • Brief, 'shock-like' involuntary single or multiple jerks —suggestive of myoclonic seizure.
    • Residual symptoms after the attack (post-ictal phenomena), such as drowsiness, headaches, amnesia, or confusion (usually occur only after generalised tonic and/or clonic seizures).

Perform a physical examination including:

  • Cardiac, neurological, and mental state, and a developmental assessment if appropriate.
  • Examination of the oral mucosa to identify lateral tongue bites.
  • Identification of any injuries sustained during the seizure.

Consider arranging baseline tests for adults with suspected epilepsy, and send the results to the specialist, when available. These may include:

  • Bloods such as full blood count, urea and electrolytes, liver function tests, glucose, and calcium. 
  • A 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG).

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Assessment after a first seizure

  • The recommendations on asking about risk factors and other potential causes of seizures are pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice and expert opinion in a review article on generalised seizures [BMJ Best Practice, 2018a]. 
  • The recommendations about what to assess in a person presenting after a first seizure are based on expert opinion in the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline The epilepsies. The diagnosis and management of the epilepsies in adults and children in primary and secondary care [National Clinical Guideline Centre, 2012b], and the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN) guideline Diagnosis and management of epilepsy in adults [SIGN, 2018], which states that the most important diagnostic information comes from a clear history from the patient and an eyewitness to the event. This is consistent with expert opinion that the diagnosis of epilepsy and epileptic seizures is largely clinical and depends on the history and examination [Gavvala and Schuele, 2016].
  • The recommendations on asking about aura and any potential triggers also reflect expert opinion in review articles [Krishnamurthy, 2016; Legg and Newton, 2017, Counselling adults who experience a first seizure]. 
  • CKS recommends asking about residual symptoms after the attack based on examples given in review articles on generalised seizures [BMJ Best Practice, 2018a; BMJ Best Practice, 2018b]. 

Classification of seizure type

  • Expert opinion in the SIGN guideline Diagnosis and management of epilepsy in adults states that the classification of seizure type has implications for management and prognosis [SIGN, 2018]. In an operational classification of seizure types, the International League Against Epilepsy (ILAE) Commission for Classification and Terminology emphasises the importance of the clinician determining that the event has the characteristics of a seizure, and then classifying seizure type [Fisher et al, 2017]. The ILAE classification systems for seizures and epilepsy syndromes are widely used and recognised in clinical practice [SIGN, 2018]. 
  • The examples of specific features of different seizure types is based on expert opinion in the NICE guideline The Epilepsies. The diagnosis and management of the epilepsies in adults and children in primary and secondary care [National Clinical Guideline Centre, 2012b]. 
  • CKS acknowledges that the diagnosis of epilepsy may be complex and beyond the scope of healthcare practitioners in primary care, and NICE and SIGN state that the diagnosis of epilepsy should be made by an epilepsy specialist [National Clinical Guideline Centre, 2012b; SIGN, 2018], but as much information as possible should be included in the referral letter to help the specialist reach a diagnosis.

Physical examination

  • The recommendation on performing a physical examination is based on the NICE guidelines Epilepsies. The diagnosis and management of the epilepsies in adults and children in primary and secondary care [National Clinical Guideline Centre, 2012b] and expert opinion in a review article on counselling adults who have had a first seizure [Legg and Newton, 2017, Counselling adults who experience a first seizure]. 

Baseline investigations for adults

  • The recommendation to perform baseline investigations for adults including bloods and electrocardiogram (ECG), and to ensure the results are available when the person is assessed in secondary care, is based on expert opinion in the NICE guideline The Epilepsies. The diagnosis and management of the epilepsies in adults and children in primary and secondary care [National Clinical Guideline Centre, 2012b], and expert opinion in review articles [Gavvala and Schuele, 2016; Krishnamurthy, 2016; Legg and Newton, 2017, Counselling adults who experience a first seizure; Thijs et al, 2019].
